## Encoding Specificity 

![](images/Experiment_kids.png){.absolute top=-50 right=-50 width="120" height="90"}

<p style="font-size: 30px;"> The principle of **encoding specificity** posits that a really important factor for recalling something is the presence of same/similar *cues*\* both at the *encoding* stage and *retrieval stage*. This effect is also sometimes referred to as "context-dependent memory". </p>


<p style ="font-size:16px; padding-top: 15px; position: absolute;  top: 180px; right: 0px; width: 370px;"> **\*Cue:** objects or events, usually present during encoding, that help trigger a memory. </p> 


![](images/Encoding Specificity.png){.absolute top=250 right=350 width=900 height=380}

![](images/Brain_thinking_R.png){.absolute top=350 right=30 width="200" height="200"}



## Encoding Specificity in Action?

![](images/Experiment_kids.png){.absolute top=-50 right=-50 width="120" height="90"}

::: {layout-ncol="2"}

::: col

::: {.fragment fragment-index="1"}
<p style="font-size: 26px;">  A classical example of this principle in the encoding specificity literature comes from Godden and Baddeley (1975):</p>
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index="2"}
<p style="font-size: 24px; padding-top: 25px;"> In this experiment, participants were asked *either* asked to learn a set of water under water or on land, and then asked to recall the learnt words *both* under water and on land. </p>
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index="3"}
<p style="font-size: 24px; padding-top: 25px;"> It was found that participants exhibited significantly better recall when the retrieval condition matched the encoding condition (e.g., water/water did better than water/land). </p>
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index="4"}
<p style="font-size: 26px; padding-top: 10px;"> Unfortunately, a recent attempt to replicated this study was not successful ([Murre, 2021](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8568063/){target="_blank"}) üò¢ </p>
:::
